[{'account_id': 21284, 'date': '2017-02-06 15:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21284, 'date': '2017-02-06 15:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-02-06 16:26:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'd like to see more thought around the design of this feature. This feels a bit thrown together to scratch an immediate itch. Choosing back end based on image disk format seems arbitrary.

I would like to see a scheme to allow a storage backend to be picked explicitly per local disk. So, for eg, root disk, additional ephemeral disks, and swap disks may reasonably be on separate backends. In the fantastical future we may also have multiple instances of the same type of storage, eg multiple ceph pools perhaps differentiated on performance."}, {'account_id': 20040, 'date': '2017-02-06 16:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Matt, thanks for feedback. I can only imagine adding additional flavor extra specs to choose image backend type per local disk type (root, ephemeral, swap).
Initial approach is about to demonstrate overall idea, that having an ability to choose image backend has some benefits rather than having it hard coded per compute node. I.e. we can avoid unnecessary image conversion to gain instance startup speedup if we store both qcow2 and raw images in Glance. I agree, that choosing backend based on source image format may be confusing however it doesn't require changing any data models. That's why I stick to it."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-02-07 11:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The Flat backend already does this if you also set force_raw_images to False. This is problematic enough already :)

My concern is principally the maintenance of this feature, or the upgrade path from this feature to a more generally useful one.'}, {'account_id': 21284, 'date': '2017-02-07 11:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I have few more examples of possible:
1) Different backends may have different performance characteristics (iops, throughput and etc). Supporting multiple image backends within a single compute node allows to provide different qos for instances spawned on that node. Currently we could achieve that only per node using i.e. host aggregates.
2) Libvirt vz driver allows to manage both containers and virtual machines thought a single libvirt connection. However VMs support qcow2/raw images while containers only ploop. So in order to spawn both VMs and containers on a single compute node we need an ability to use multiple images backends for different instances.

We would need to define whether we want to specify image backend separately for different local disk types and how to specify that.'}, {'account_id': 21284, 'date': '2017-02-07 11:36:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also it seems that this feature should land on top of your imagebackend refactoring efforts.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-02-24 21:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I remain very much against this, because this configuration should not be static. The current configuration is static, and it already complicates:

* Deployments with heterogeneous storage
* Migrations
* Upgrades

Doubling down on existing technical debt is not going to do either developers or users any favours.

For example, this change allows a user to have ploop images in glance used natively by Nova. Firstly, as I mentioned in a previous comment the Flat backend already has this behaviour (and it uses a per-instance store to know it did it). If you want to add this behaviour minimally invasively you should investigate doing it here, with no additional config variables.

Secondly, the change you have proposed is going to break all existing instances which were created from Ploop glance images but stored in Nova as something other than Ploop. With this static design there is nothing you can reasonably do about this, because it's all or nothing. There is no way to represent that some instances use an old layout and others use a new layout.

I would very much like to see us persist driver-specific storage configuration in the BDM. I would like to see us unambiguously record at a bare minimum which backend is in use for each disk. This will allow us to make this kind of change safely without resorting to adding more layers of complex and fragile heuristics."}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2017-03-27 10:10:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

>I remain very much against this, because this configuration should not be static. 

And this new behavor doesn't do any static configuration. Rather it moves us closer to dynamic one. In fact it just ignores one static ridiculous thing called 'images_type' for ploop images.

> For example, this change allows a user to have ploop images in glance used natively by Nova.

No, it's not true. Currently users *are* able to use ploop images and this code doen's allow this.

> with no additional config variables

A new version doesn't introduce any additional config variables so I can't understand how this will complicate deployment migrations and upgrade. Maybe you are referring the previos version of the change?

> Secondly, the change you have proposed is going to break all existing instances which were created from Ploop glance images but stored in Nova as something other than Ploop.

I'm 100% sure there is no such cases thus, we are not breaking anything.

> I would very much like to see us persist driver-specific storage configuration in the BDM

This is doable

> I would like to see us unambiguously record at a bare minimum which backend is in use for each disk

And this is immediately possible as we undestand what format of disk images an instance has.

> This will allow us to make this kind of change safely without resorting to adding more layers of complex and fragile heuristics.

Didn't get what kind of heuristics you are referencing. There are 1:1 relationships for created disk images and backends: qcow2<->qcow2, flat(raw)<->flat, ploop<->ploop. Do you mean that for some reason we have to use something different?"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-03-27 10:48:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

You're right, I scanned this a bit too quickly and missed that you're now using an image property rather than a config variable.

However, this doesn't change anything because the configuration still isn't per-instance. For example, if a user had previously configured a host with images_type='qcow2', and had uploaded a glance image with disk_format='ploop', this would would have been converted to a qcow2 disk. With this change Nova will now expect this to be a ploop disk instead, but it isn't, so operations on the instance will fail.

If we're going to add any more layers to this code, we must store per-instance (per-disk really) configuration first. Otherwise we start adding layers of heuristics like checking which backing file naming style is in use by the qcow2 driver, or whether our config disk was created on rbd or raw."}, {'account_id': 21284, 'date': '2017-04-06 08:31:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-06 10:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

[{'created': '2017-02-06 15:13:33.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Runtime image type detection

This change allows image backend to be chosen based on source image
format rather than having image backend specified per compute node in
config option `images_type`.
We introduced new config option `images_type_mapping`, that
maps source image type to desired image backend.
If `images_type_mapping` is empty or not specified or image format is
not defined in mapping, then `images_type` is used to choose image
backend as usual.

Implements: blueprint runtime-image-type
Change-Id: I19bb2c1b4417b8a11077ec9963332a2065e4001c
Signed-off-by: Pavel Gluschak <pglushchak@virtuozzo.com>

commit_message:
WIP: honor disk_format=ploop image metadata property

This change allows to use 'ploop' image backend even when 'images_type'
is set to other disk image format types like qcow2 or flat.
We honor 'disk_format=ploop' image metadata property over config parameter
'images_type' to chose desired image backend.
If 'disk_format' is not equal to 'ploop', then `images_type` is used to choose
image backend as usual.

Implements: blueprint image-type-mapping
Change-Id: I19bb2c1b4417b8a11077ec9963332a2065e4001c
Signed-off-by: Pavel Gluschak <pglushchak@virtuozzo.com>
Signed-off-by: Maxim Nestratov <mnestratov@virtuozzo.com>

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

The detail is described in the following links:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

doc8 command is dropped from docs and releasenotes tox envs.
We run doc8 in pep8 tox env, so this hurts nothing.

Change-Id: I24271b527258b1de4cf26ca7efd625954eb834de

commit_message:
libvirt: Fix instance's cleaned was incorrect after live-migration.

After block live-migration, instance's cleaned was set True. It
was not consistent with instance's deleted value that was False.

This patch modify this problem, after delete instace's files on
source or destination compute node while instance live-migration,
the value of instance's cleaned is False.

Closes-Bug:#1598353

Change-Id: I78f79eed71deec5e18d79a7a12104eb6ed38e616

commit_message:
update required kernel

The required kernel was set to 4.2 though that's not an option in
xenial. This change updates the required kernel to 4.4.

Change-Id: I09c4c241f0c4ba1e62a34d76fd3f7ce8d6486c6f

commit_message:
Bump max-servers limestone nodepool provider to 10

We've manually and successfully tested a virtual machine with the
nodepool image and the ipv6 network.
The virtual machine could reach the regional mirror and a devstack-gate
reproduce.sh ran to completion.

Let's do an initial bump to 10 nodes to monitor for failures we could
not catch -- we'll bump to 50 afterwards if we're confident things are
working well for both us and Limestone.

Change-Id: I3a3b68dd9fbd0243f3544ceceb4859aa6d435fc8

[{'created': '2018-03-27 09:18:43.000000000', 'message': "Make tumbleweed integration test non-voting

There seems to be a bug with tumbleweed and openvswitch.

The integration job fails with [1]

 2018-03-27 08:12:44.524005 | TASK [multi-node-bridge : Ensure openvswitch is started]
 2018-03-27 08:12:45.546845 | secondary | ERROR: Unable to start service openvswitch: A dependency job for openvswitch.service failed. See 'journalctl -xe' for details.
 2018-03-27 08:12:45.586488 | primary | ERROR: Unable to start service openvswitch: A dependency job for openvswitch.service failed. See 'journalctl -xe' for details.

If you install openvswitch on a suse host, it fails to start.  The
journal contains

 ovsdb-server[29316]: ovs|00002|daemon_unix|EMER|/var/run/openvswitch/ovsdb-server.pid.tmp: create failed (Permission denied)
 ovs-ctl[29267]: ovsdb-server: /var/run/openvswitch/ovsdb-server.pid.tmp: create failed (Permission denied)

 systemd[1]: ovsdb-server.service: Control process exited, code=exited status=1

 systemd[1]: Failed to start Open vSwitch Database Unit.

This appears to be the same problem as [2] which boils down to a
systemd/openvswitch incompatability.  Pending reporting and fixing
this upstream, make the test non-voting.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/76/556776/1/check/openstack-infra-multinode-integration-opensuse-tumbleweed/393fa10/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-27_08_12_44_524005

commit_message:
Make tumbleweed integration test non-voting

There seems to be a bug with tumbleweed and openvswitch.

The integration job fails with [1]

 2018-03-27 08:12:44.524005 | TASK [multi-node-bridge : Ensure openvswitch is started]
 2018-03-27 08:12:45.546845 | secondary | ERROR: Unable to start service openvswitch: A dependency job for openvswitch.service failed. See 'journalctl -xe' for details.
 2018-03-27 08:12:45.586488 | primary | ERROR: Unable to start service openvswitch: A dependency job for openvswitch.service failed. See 'journalctl -xe' for details.

If you install openvswitch on a suse host, it fails to start.  The
journal contains

 ovsdb-server[29316]: ovs|00002|daemon_unix|EMER|/var/run/openvswitch/ovsdb-server.pid.tmp: create failed (Permission denied)
 ovs-ctl[29267]: ovsdb-server: /var/run/openvswitch/ovsdb-server.pid.tmp: create failed (Permission denied)
 ovs-ctl[29267]: Starting ovsdb-server ... failed!
 systemd[1]: ovsdb-server.service: Control process exited, code=exited status=1
 systemd[1]: ovsdb-server.service: Failed with result 'exit-code'.
 systemd[1]: Failed to start Open vSwitch Database Unit.

This appears to be the same problem as [2] which boils down to a
systemd/openvswitch incompatability.  Pending reporting and fixing
this upstream, make the test non-voting.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/76/556776/1/check/openstack-infra-multinode-integration-opensuse-tumbleweed/393fa10/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-27_08_12_44_524005
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1508495

Change-Id: I6ce5b14713a341c6c90ac860f6f843cf3d014abc

commit_message:
WIP: fullstack: Put all services into namespaces

All neutron processes will be run in namespace that represents a host.
Those hosts running openvswitch agent will also have their own
ovsdb-server and ovs-vswitchd processes. A native ovsdb interface is
provided from the OpenvSwitchFixture in order to provide test runner
capability to configure host ovs intefaces.

Missing:
     - investigate why ovs-agent reports ip is not available
     - new docs
     - start l3 agents
     - start dhcp agents
     - start linuxbridge agents
     - make test pass

Change-Id: Ie7997080de931910ae0635eaa6493fe98b0323d0

commit_message:
tasks: Do not check the load balancer uri for API status

Configuring the cinder backends requires the API to be up and running.
Whilst this is normally the case, in HA deployments we normally take
down the haproxy backend to configure the services so the API is not
responding and configuring the backends leads to failures. As such, lets
query the API host directly to determine the API status instead of going
via the load balancer.

Change-Id: I1a08ca771b5a4bb6c13a81a96c7fc826b6fee858
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/553936/
Closes-Bug: #1753125

they also default to docker. Without this change users of these
services could end up with mismatched (unsupported) deployments.

Additionally, this picks environment/services-docker as the

environment/services. So environment/services now contain all of

commit_message:
Default environment/services/* to docker

This updates the relevant environment/services templates so that
they also default to docker. Without this change users of these
services could end up with mismatched (unsupported) deployments.

Additionally, this picks environment/services-docker as the
source of truth when resolving collisions for moving those over
environment/services. So environment/services now contain all of
the containerized services' env files used to be located in
environment/services-docker. The latter will be deleted later to
prevent future desync of contents.

Co-authored-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I923731f46ea26582160a11d2dfe85792ab74110b

Delete not-used services-docker files

Change-Id: Iad365d231b081a7f711df79e9a254873dabe8bc9
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
rpc collector

active-active Collector service, detached from vitrage-graph service,
 exposing it's methods by RPC, so to only run when needed.

Change-Id: I21fdc03a4c7477e224ca0a5ae384de98ee48e2af

[{'created': '2018-03-14 14:07:58.000000000', 'message': 'Adjust openshift-ansible ansible config

These changes are to enable running via mistral, so e.g deploying
via openstack overcloud deploy --config-download works - currently
this fails because the "inner" ansible-playbook tries to write
/home/mistral/.ssh which fails

Change-Id: I882592cab3a8dec2d2522e7d763f1d0adda72a86
'}]
commit_message:
Adjust openshift-ansible ansible config

These changes are to enable running via mistral, so e.g deploying
via openstack overcloud deploy --config-download works - currently
this fails because the "inner" ansible-playbook tries to write
/home/mistral/.ssh which fails

Change-Id: I882592cab3a8dec2d2522e7d763f1d0adda72a86

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

--
neutron-vpnaas-dashboard specific:
horizon needs to install horizon master via tox-siblings,
so horizon needs to be specified as required-projects.

Change-Id: I1fc69c9809d408fdf1fb825bef58189d72fda716
Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 22:20:48.000000000', 'message': 'Upgrade data on disk on mysql major upgrade - non HA

During major upgrade of non-HA overcloud, paunch stops the
containerized mysql service, update container image and restart
the containerized mysql.

After a major update of mysql (e.g. 5.5 to 10.0), run mysql_upgrade
to ensure that database on-disk is upgraded to match the mysql
server version (e.g. update all MyISAM tables)

The mysql_upgrade cannot be performed during upgrade_steps because
paunch only runs during the deploy_steps. So run it in the
post_upgrade_steps, once we know paunch has updated mysql.

Change-Id: I6b6a531fd716ad9abcbf29886c0b1f2c64f04c9d
'}]
commit_message:
Upgrade data on disk on mysql major upgrade - non HA

During major upgrade of non-HA overcloud, paunch stops the
containerized mysql service, update container image and restart
the containerized mysql.

After a major update of mysql (e.g. 5.5 to 10.0), run mysql_upgrade
to ensure that database on-disk is upgraded to match the mysql
server version (e.g. update all MyISAM tables)

The mysql_upgrade cannot be performed during upgrade_steps because
paunch only runs during the deploy_steps. So run it in the
post_upgrade_steps, once we know paunch has updated mysql.

Change-Id: I6b6a531fd716ad9abcbf29886c0b1f2c64f04c9d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-13 11:05:44.000000000', 'message': 'Do not depend on jenkins user in devstack gate

As announced on openstack-dev [1] openstack-infra images no longer have
the jenkins user. The functional (devstack gate based) test suite of the
osc-placement repo depended on the jenkins user in its post_test_hook.
Because of that dependecy all functional test suite runs of
osc-placement started to fail after [2] was merged.

We fix the functional test suite of osc-placement by no longer using the
jenkins user.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/
           2018-February/127800.html
[2] https://review.openstack.org/514485/

Change-Id: I966fb6d16b0086fc5fe345fdb695dbbed2eb4299
'}, {'created': '2018-03-13 12:52:21.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Do not depend on jenkins user in devstack gate

As announced on openstack-dev [1] openstack-infra images no longer have
the jenkins user. The functional (devstack gate based) test suite of the
osc-placement repo depended on the jenkins user in its post_test_hook.
Because of that dependecy all functional test suite runs of
osc-placement started to fail after [2] was merged.

We fix the functional test suite of osc-placement by no longer using the
jenkins user.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/

hardcoding the jenkins user.

Ideally we would not need root in post_test_hook. However it seems
devstack installs globally (as root) the master branch of osc-placement
(in develop mode) resulting the following directory being owned by root:

/opt/stack/new/osc-placement/osc_placement.egg-info/

When 'tox -e functional' tries to install the commit under test of
osc-placement in the tox functional venv (also in develop mode from the
same repo directory) but as a non-privileged user that conflicts with
the previous global installation.

It'd be nice to remove the need for root altogether, but at the moment
I don't know how to do that.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/
           2018-February/127800.html
[2] https://review.openstack.org/514485/

Change-Id: I966fb6d16b0086fc5fe345fdb695dbbed2eb4299

commit_message:
Do not depend on jenkins user in devstack gate

As announced on openstack-dev [1] openstack-infra images no longer have
the jenkins user. The functional (devstack gate based) test suite of the
osc-placement repo depended on the jenkins user in its post_test_hook.
Because of that dependecy all functional test suite runs of
osc-placement started to fail after [2] was merged.

We fix the functional test suite of osc-placement by no longer
hardcoding the jenkins user.

Ideally we would not need root in post_test_hook. However it seems
devstack installs globally (as root) the master branch of osc-placement
(in develop mode) resulting the following directory being owned by root:

/opt/stack/new/osc-placement/osc_placement.egg-info/

When 'tox -e functional' tries to install the commit under test of
osc-placement in the tox functional venv (also in develop mode from the
same repo directory) but as a non-privileged user that conflicts with
the previous global installation.

It'd be nice to remove the need for root altogether, but at the moment
I don't know how to do that.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/
           2018-February/127800.html
[2] https://review.openstack.org/514485/

Change-Id: I966fb6d16b0086fc5fe345fdb695dbbed2eb4299

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-19 15:08:24.000000000', 'message': 'Resolution for minimal SIG governance

We have been operating SIGs for some time now with a very loose
governance model. We took this approach on purpose to give folks
space and opportunity to decide what they believed constituted
a SIG in hopes of learning how we can apply SIGs to our community
needs.

However at this point there is some confusion and concern regarding
SIG governance. Since SIGs explicitly do not sit below any existing
governance structure, there is no default solution to fall back on.
We need to define a clear way to address issues before any conflict
arises. As was the case elsewhere, we expect the mere existence of
a clear decision-making structure to prevent most conflicts from
happening.

This resolution proposes a minimal, simple governance model to
address such cases, introducing a SIGs admin group. The group
is initially formed of the Meta SIG co-leads: Melvin Hillsman
as UC representative and Thierry Carrez as TC representative.
The committees are of course free to choose new members whenever
they see fit.

A similar resolution was proposed to the User Committee, which
approved it:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/uc/2018/uc.2018-03-12-14.05.log.html#l-74

Change-Id: Ibc2336980739db38f64a42b8ba2adeacff000a13
Co-Authored-By: Melvin Hillsman <mrhillsman@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Resolution for minimal SIG governance

We have been operating SIGs for some time now with a very loose
governance model. We took this approach on purpose to give folks
space and opportunity to decide what they believed constituted
a SIG in hopes of learning how we can apply SIGs to our community
needs.

However at this point there is some confusion and concern regarding
SIG governance. Since SIGs explicitly do not sit below any existing
governance structure, there is no default solution to fall back on.
We need to define a clear way to address issues before any conflict
arises. As was the case elsewhere, we expect the mere existence of
a clear decision-making structure to prevent most conflicts from
happening.

This resolution proposes a minimal, simple governance model to
address such cases, introducing a SIGs admin group. The group
is initially formed of the Meta SIG co-leads: Melvin Hillsman
as UC representative and Thierry Carrez as TC representative.
The committees are of course free to choose new members whenever
they see fit.

A similar resolution was proposed to the User Committee, which
approved it:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/uc/2018/uc.2018-03-12-14.05.log.html#l-74

Change-Id: Ibc2336980739db38f64a42b8ba2adeacff000a13
Co-Authored-By: Melvin Hillsman <mrhillsman@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

Remove the '[build_sphinx]' and '[pbr]' sections as described in:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128594.html

Change-Id: I65b35db580e029bb0639c7b4bd1cb7c3b0395542

commit_message:
Update new projects reference WRT IRC meetings.

In I631e2597bf818c5e4b2f813da14764d2cb55d0ce the TC passed
resolutions/20170718-allow-scheduling-meetings-on-team-channels which
allows teams to host meetings in per-project IRC channels.

However the new-projects-requirements still stated that meeting needed
to be held in one of the central meeting channels.  This change updates
that document in light of the resolution.

Change-Id: Ib8febcc6b80bc36833f2040b1cc1c5eb15841655

commit_message:
Move password generation to deployment phase

This changes when the passords are generated to be done
not during plan creation but during deploy.

Change-Id: I67e2a9f97ec9bb63a1d7212e2649797c1ef0f790
Closes-bug: #1664521

commit_message:
Support parsing ini files with no sections

Services such as Zookeeper and Kafka use ini files which do not
explicitly specify sections. This change supports merging ini
files with no sections, so that the configuration for these
services follows the example configuration provided for them
as closely as possible.

Closes-Bug: #1756101
Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I1061729875e5545c7af7d80779f9c2124b6c7134

commit_message:
Removing remaining Tempest bits

All the Neutron Stadium projects are importing Tempest code from the
neutron-tempest-plugin repo. We can now safely remove the remaining
bits of Tempest code.

Depends-On: I34efe893b93240c4689de1dda978209926022dfd
Change-Id: I2cf6e1f60926f36384bf056066bcdd4e0301494f

commit_message:
Add base jobs for functional tests

I keep copy-pasting these to projects from the shade repo. Let's make
some base jobs people can more easily use.

devstack-tox-functional runs devstack and a tox functional environment.

devstack-tox-functional-consumer is the same, but runs devstack in pre.
It's intended for projects for whom patches to the project won't
actually impact the devstack deployment (shade, nodepool, gophercloud
are all examples of such things)

Change-Id: I84de60181cb88574e341ff83cd4857cce241f2dd
(cherry picked from commit e1b0c3886ba5551d3fa8c79849d6a6406037c811)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-12 14:03:37.000000000', 'message': 'Support cross AZ backups

Add support for microversion 3.51 that allows us to specify the
Availability Zone of the backup service that should create the backup.

New optional parameter available for "backup-create" when using
microversion 3.51 is "--availability-zone".

Depends-On: I595932276088d25abd464025c99dce33a2cc502b
Change-Id: Ia4bab5fcb95f6a8d1adb99c5d7dc1b3f7546c6f6
'}]
commit_message:
Support cross AZ backups

Add support for microversion 3.51 that allows us to specify the
Availability Zone of the backup service that should create the backup.

New optional parameter available for "backup-create" when using
microversion 3.51 is "--availability-zone".

Depends-On: I595932276088d25abd464025c99dce33a2cc502b
Change-Id: Ia4bab5fcb95f6a8d1adb99c5d7dc1b3f7546c6f6

'}, {'created': '2018-03-13 06:00:54.000000000', 'message': "playbooks: containers-lxc-host: Set correct disk size limit for containers

* We need to set the lxc_host_machine_volume_size variable based on the
  size of the disk which holds the container images.

* To ensure we're using the extra data-disks correctly the bootstrap role
  has been updated to correctly handle mounts using systemd mount units
  and oneshot services.

* This change sets the container path accordingly allowing an extra
  physical datadisk to be used for all of our container backends.

Change-Id: I0dc6daabad6c071ec7f9013a1e1eb0b3e594b544
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

"}, {'created': '2018-03-14 21:34:45.000000000', 'message': "Convert role to use a common systemd role(s)

This removes the systemd service templates and tasks from this role and
leverages a common systemd roles instead. This change removes a lot of
code duplication across all governed projects without sacrificing features
or functionality. The intention of this change is to ensure uniformity and
reduce the maintenance burden on the community when sweeping changes are
needed.

* To ensure we're using the extra data-disks correctly the bootstrap role
  has been updated to correctly handle mounts using systemd mount units
  and oneshot services.

* This change sets the container path accordingly allowing an extra
  physical datadisk to be used for all of our container backends.

* The gate test functionality can now be used with all of our container
  storage backends. This makes it possible for folks using all of our
  available options, [dir, machinectl, btrfs, lvm, zfs] to test an integrated
  build of OSA by simply setting the `lxc_container_backing_store` just as it
  would be done in a production deployment.

Change-Id: I0dc6daabad6c071ec7f9013a1e1eb0b3e594b544
Co-Authored-By: Markos Chandras <mchandras@suse.de>
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-03-14 21:37:57.000000000', 'message': "Convert role to use a common systemd role(s)

commit_message:
Convert role to use a common systemd role(s)

This removes the systemd service templates and tasks from this role and
leverages a common systemd roles instead. This change removes a lot of
code duplication across all governed projects without sacrificing features
or functionality. The intention of this change is to ensure uniformity and
reduce the maintenance burden on the community when sweeping changes are
needed.

* To ensure we're using the extra data-disks correctly the bootstrap role
  has been updated to correctly handle mounts using systemd mount units
  and oneshot services.

* This change sets the container path accordingly allowing an extra
  physical datadisk to be used for all of our container backends.

* The gate test functionality can now be used with all of our container
  storage backends. This makes it possible for folks using all of our
  available options, [dir, machinectl, btrfs, lvm, zfs] to test an integrated
  build of OSA by simply setting the `lxc_container_backing_store` just as it
  would be done in a production deployment.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org//555614
Change-Id: I0dc6daabad6c071ec7f9013a1e1eb0b3e594b544
Co-Authored-By: Markos Chandras <mchandras@suse.de>
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Change-Id: Ib1838be4ecd55a070fa30990b25f3135b60c35d4
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ib1838be4ecd55a070fa30990b25f3135b60c35d4
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Standardize '_get_XXX_constraint' functions

There are a number of functions that take image_meta and flavor
objects, validate the values and return something. Standardize the
naming and calling of these and add a load of documentation to help
folks navigate this stuff.

Change-Id: I4516387b5b27b9a447c98dd5748858b6de634a99

Please add unit test for this change.'}, {'account_id': 27060, 'date': '2017-11-22 10:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18653, 'date': '2017-11-22 11:09:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Hi Mateusz!

Thanks for the patch!
I'd like to propose the order is changed, instance first node second; specific first generic second. Let's see what folks think about it though.

I'm voting -1 because of a missing release note and missing unit test coverage for the change.

Cheers,
milan"}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2017-11-22 11:34:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I was thinking about the order and agree in general we should have specific first, generic second. However the following use case came out as described in the launchpad -- we have an image which specifies disk_label=msdos and we try to deploy it in a node with huge hard drives. This would fail even if for the node we specify disk_label=gpt, as the instance info took precedence.

But still, I may be missing a bigger picture in here. In general I think we all agree the disk_label parameter from the node itself shouldn't be ignored like it's now. About the order, yes, let's see what people think"}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2017-12-01 10:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2017-12-01 11:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Hi! This needs a release note, and I'd like to hear more about the use case. Is it for large disk support?

I'm not sure it's going to play well with traits, when we switch to them. If the problem is in large disks, maybe we should just default to GPT for them?"}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2017-12-01 12:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- dell-hwFX2-tempest-dsvm-ironic-pxe_ipmitool https://stash.dellemc-community.org/logs/75/521975/5/check/dell-hwFX2-tempest-dsvm-ironic-pxe_ipmitool/a7d1d1f/ : SUCCESS in 36m 48s'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-12-06 17:04:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

IMO nothing in capabilities should be used to change behaviour, it should define what a node is capable of, and instance_info then informs ironic what it should do.

It appears the problem being described in the bug is because the flavor isn't being used to specify to select the capability of gpt in the extra specs. If its specified in the extra_specs of your flavor then nova will match it to the node and then include it in the instance_info.

I think if we want to have a different default per node (e.g. when it isn't specified in the flavor) then it shouldn't be part of the capabilities but should be in driver_info['default_disk_label'] or something like that.

I believe we used to have some logic somewhere which actually detected the size of the hard disk and would automatically change the default to gpt if we detected the disk was too large to use MBR. I'm not sure if that logic still exists or not but should be worth reviving if its broken."}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2017-12-18 09:40:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Sam, I have checked and the last one doesn't seem to be true ...

Having added "disk_label='gpt'" as a property of the flavour, having "disk_label:gpt" as a capability of the node, "instance_info" field for "ironic node-show" doesn't expose "disk_label" what means it wasn't populated.

Seems nova has used disk_label for scheduling so it selected the proper node, but for an unknown reason didn't pass anything from the extra specs into instance_info'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-12-18 14:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Hi Sam, I have checked and the last one doesn't seem to be true ...
 > 
 > Having added "disk_label='gpt'" as a property of the flavour,
 > having "disk_label:gpt" as a capability of the node,
 > "instance_info" field for "ironic node-show" doesn't expose
 > "disk_label" what means it wasn't populated.
 > 
 > Seems nova has used disk_label for scheduling so it selected the
 > proper node, but for an unknown reason didn't pass anything from
 > the extra specs into instance_info

To set the option on the nova flavor, you need to prefix with "capabilities:" e.g. 

  nova flavor-key baremetal set capabilities:disk_label="gpt"'}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2018-01-09 09:39:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Well, I still seem to have problems with passing it into instance_info, even with your syntax...
http://paste.openstack.org/raw/641071/'}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2018-01-10 12:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Okay, it seems like indeed nova can be forced to propagate this info from the flavour, so the change can be dropped as the required functionality can be achieved using another approach ...'}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2018-03-27 07:42:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Use disk_label from node.capabilities

When disk_label is defined as a capability of the node and
is not defined in instance_info passed by nova, use it instead of
relying on a default value.

In case the label is set both for ironic node and nova instance,
the latter shall have a priority.

Change-Id: I25be88da41e36ad15eaeb887931f9995740d291b
Closes-bug: #1733663

commit_message:
Add affinity score check attribute to flavor

This change request is to enable adding affinity score check
attribute as part of VM deploy based on the host capability.

Change-Id: I63b80fc80ef6634396a460d74794216b09ed2f2d

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I312f591a68fa30636502eadb563de5656faca3e9
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Django 2.0 support

Add py35dj20 to test Django 2.0 integration
Also drops py27dj18 support since Django 1.10 is
the primary version of Django support and it is covered
by py27.

Change-Id: Id2e782e9165c2f7145dc005c5f4eeff1c69cdd7b
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <zulcss@ubuntu.com>
